ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of new grammar and word order rules that helped me form more complex sentences when speaking and writing.
I think that I improved immensely in my ability to speak, understand, read, and write German in this course. It was a fully immersive experience, and I think this helped me on the learning curve.
Foundational German grammar such as German adjective endings, genitive tense, subjunctive mood, and modern German culture
I developed a good grasp for basic German grammar and a knowledge for the best techniques to learn Deutsch at home.
I learned how to better understand spoken German, but still struggled speaking it myself.
I really improved my german, especially in reading and speaking. In class we are expected to only speak in german and that is very beneficial
I developed the skills necessary to have basic conversations in any tense.
I learned second level German
Ability to understand another language, think in a different way relative to other classes I have taken
I improved all of my German skills and learned about German society and culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths of this course are the speaking activities. The one weakness for me was the final project; I found that it added a lot to my workload while not really improving my German.

Though intimidating, the class being fully conducted in German helped me gain a lot of knowledge of the language quickly. I think the main focus was slanted slightly towards grammar and structures, but I think that this was very helpful in gaining overall competence of the language. I do wish we spent a bit more time practicing and integrating the vocabulary. The class was very interactive and got us speaking and writing a lot with other students, which helped improve skill and confidence.
Strengths: very systematic and organized. Prof. Gehlker was also very accommodating and kind.

Strengths: 
Good in class pace/discussions
Teacher uses German at an appropriate level in class
Effective homework exercises
Appropriate tests/grading

Weaknesses:
Repetitive homework (we have been assigned the same exercise in class/Connect/asynchronous
I think we could have watched a bit more of "real" Germans speak, since speaking to a classmate is not very realistic, and their German is usually very poor.
The homework was brutal. I felt as though it took me hours on end and most of my time and energy was spent on German class as opposed to the several other classes i was taking.
Strength is the helpful textbook and weakness is the large amount of busy work that takes forever to do.
Sometimes a lot of repetitive homeworks etc, would prefer to spend more time on some concepts
The material is delivered in a systematic way which made it easier to retain. The biggest weakness was communication regarding certain assessments. Sometimes they appeared without much warning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. German is a really fun language to learn, and this class really expands on L1 so that you can say and write way more things. The work can be a little overwhelming at times but definitely worth it in my opinion.

Yes! I think that the German courses can be tough, but they are challenging in a way that is extremely helpful. You get out of this course what you put in, but this course really advanced my knowledge of the language.
For those seeking a language credit, I would definitely recommend it, although it requires a significant amount of time and effort invested by the student.
Yes, if you are trying to actually learn German! The workload is pretty high, but you improve quickly!
Probably not, unless they are very interested and wanting to speak German, otherwise I would tell them that it is far too much work.
Yes. Prof. Gehlkers course is challenging but great. I recommend 120 to students who have taken 110 at Yale
German is a great language and if you like it then you should definitely take this course.
Yes, it is a useful language
Yes, the course definitely helped me improve and grow more confident in my German.
